qas.question: Well-fed animals in captivity can become friends with prey animals due to what motivation?

answers.text: mutual advantage or fear of reprisal from human masters

qas.question: Why would cats and dogs potentially become companions in captivity?
Captive animals can distinguish co-inhabitats from what other group?

plausible_answers.text: from peaceful coexistence to close companionship

qas.question: What kind of relationships to people have in rural areas?
Why is there less crime in rural areas?
How do residents feel about someone harming a person in a rural area?
What are two things neighbors depend on each other for in rural areas?
What can people from rural areas differentiate captive animals from?

context: It has been observed that well-fed predator animals in a lax captivity (for instance, pet or farm animals) will usually differentiate between putative prey animals who are familiar co-inhabitants in the same human area from <a2_0><b7_0>wild ones outside the area<b7_0/><a2_0/>. This interaction can range <b3_0>from peaceful coexistence to close companionship<b3_0/>; motivation to ignore the predatory instinct may result from <a0_0>mutual advantage or <b4_0>fear of reprisal<b4_0/> from human masters<a0_0/> who have made clear that harming co-inhabitants <b5_0>will not be tolerated<b5_0/>. Pet cats and pet mice, for example, may live together in the same human residence without incident as companions. Pet cats and pet dogs under human mastership often depend on each other for <a1_0>warmth, <b6_0>companionship, and even protection<b6_0/><a1_0/>, particularly in rural areas.
